cross_references.symbolic_note: Parallel account of the temptation; Spirit drives Jesus into the wilderness.
Parallel account emphasizing Jesus being full of the Holy Spirit and tempted for forty days.
Israel tested in the wilderness; lesson that man does not live by bread alone.
God calls the soul into the wilderness to speak tenderly and restore covenant love.
The very Psalm the tempter misquotes about angels bearing you up.
You shall worship the LORD your God and Him only shall you serve.
You shall not put the LORD your God to the test.
Moses fasting forty days and nights on the mountain; pattern of intense divine encounter.
Israel’s forty years in the wilderness mirror Jesus’ forty days.
People walking in darkness see a great light; quoted later in this same chapter (Matthew 4:15–16).
The wicked compared to the troubled sea; contrast to Jesus’ inner peace under testing.
Later teaching that fruit reveals the reality within; echoes the idea of temptation revealing true heart.

metadata.theme: Knowledge vs. Love / The Weak Conscience

cross_references.symbolic_note: Love 'is not boastful' (contrast to knowledge that 'puffs up'); Love builds.
Parallel passage emphasizing not judging one another and not making freedom a stumbling block.
The principle continued: 'All things are lawful... but not all things edify. Let no one seek his own good.'
Paul's application of the principle: he is free from all, yet makes himself a servant to win more.
The entire body 'builds itself up in love,' confirming love is the construction material of the Body.
Jesus' severe warning about causing one of the 'little ones' to stumble.
